content: hey vets i enlisted in 1977 and have never used my gi bill and now that i want to use it i just found out i am ineligable due to their is a ten year statue of limitations for me to use it, gee sounds like all promises made to me by our goverment is all lies more and more as the days go by. health care,education,support to all our veterans seems the same goverment we protected and served is the same goverment that is now not protecting and serving us .
reply: hey vets i enlisted in 1977 and have never used my gi bill and now that i want to use it i just found out i am ineligable due to their is a ten year statue of limitations for me to use it, gee sounds like all promises made to me by our goverment is all lies more and more as the days go by. health care,education,support to all our veterans seems the same goverment we protected and served is the same goverment that is now not protecting and serving us .
title: g i bill benefits

content: We all knew the expiration date of the Montgomery-era GI Bill when we enlisted. As you said, ten years is the cut off date. I am currently enrolled in college, and my GI Bill expired in 2003. Do what I do and use your grants and federal student aid to pay for your classes. The VA does offer you a bit of help - I think I got a $700 grant for this year from them. It doesn't sound like much, but every little bit helps. Speaking only for myself, I did not serve to earn free college money. I love this nation, and I love all who choose to serve this nation. Being upset over an expired GI Bill just isn't worthy of my consideration... though I admit that I wish I still had the benefit to fall back on. If you truly want your education, do whatever it takes to get it. I assure you, it is rewarding! I love college (I attend online) and I have enough research under my belt to know where I can expect my MA to take me. Trust me, my friend - it is worth all the effort! It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: A service connected disability of 20% can reinstate those education benefits. any time left over unused from the first ten years can be applied. Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?

content: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: A service connected disability of 20% can reinstate those education benefits. any time left over unused from the first ten years can be applied. I had no idea. That is GREAT! The cost of school is outrageous these days, and our vets deserve all the breaks we can give them. My tuition is like $335 a credit hour, and once I am in my MA program that will jump to over $450/CH. I don't regret a single second of my 8-year enlistment, but it sure would have been nice to learn a trade and a skillset other than pulling a trigger - which doesn't equate to too many jobs in demand in the civilian sector. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: Dude go down to the DVA office, get your medical records out prior; all you need is 20% from VA, so ringing in your ears if you have med records to support it and you can say your ****** doesnt work anymore, you earned it. There are ton's of people out their that fake the funk and get full benifits, I'm sure you have enough service connected disabilty to qualify.
